An increase in local speed on the lower surface of the cylinder and a decrease in local speed on the lower surface.
An increase in local speed on the lower surface of the cylinder and a decrease in local speed on the lower surface.

Questions.QuestionString: The turbulent boundary layer also produces?
Answers: Lower kinetic energy next to the surface and this reduces the tendency for a flow separation.
Higher kinetic energy next to the surface and this increase the tendency for a flow separation.
Higher kinetic energy next to the surface and this increase the tendency for a flow separation.

Questions.QuestionString: When we have a flow separation at the root of the wing, the center of lift?
Answers: Moves towards the root and also behind the center of gravity.
Moves towards the tip and also before the center of gravity.
Moves towards the tip and also before the center of gravity.

Questions.QuestionString: When does the angle of incidence change?
Answers: When the aircraft is ascending or descending.
When the aircraft is ascending or descending.

Questions.QuestionString: If the wing span is infinite the circulation around the profile causes?
Answers: An downwash on the leading edge and a downwash on the trailing edge.
An upwash on the leading edge and a downwash on the trailing edge.
An upwash on the leading edge and a downwash on the trailing edge.

Questions.QuestionString: Upper surface frost and especially leading edge ice formation reduce?
Answers: The maximum coefficient of drag and the maximum angle of attack.
The maximum coefficient of lift and the maximum angle of attack.
The maximum coefficient of lift and the maximum angle of attack.

Questions.QuestionString: A flow separation at the tip of the wing is much more dangerous. It causes?
Answers: The center of lift moves towards the root and also forward of the center of gravity.
The center of lift moves towards the root and also aft of the center of gravity.
The center of lift moves towards the root and also aft of the center of gravity.

Questions.QuestionString: Different wing shapes are?
Answers: An elliptical wing, a rectangular wing, a tapered wing, a swept wing
An elliptical wing, a swept wing
An elliptical wing, a swept wing

Questions.QuestionString: On an aerodynamically twisted wing the camber of the profile at the root is?
Answers: Smaller than the camber at the tip and the angle of incidence is constant across the wing span.
Greater than the camber at the tip and the angle of incidence is constant across the wing span.
Greater than the camber at the tip and the angle of incidence is constant across the wing span.

Questions.QuestionString: On a geometrically twisted wing the camber of the profile is?
Answers: Smaller than the camber at the tip and the angle of incidence is constant across the wing span.
Constant across the span of the wing but the angle of incidence is greater at the root than at the tip.
Constant across the span of the wing but the angle of incidence is greater at the root than at the tip.

Questions.QuestionString: When the position of the center of lift moves forward of the position of the center of gravity we have?
Answers: No nose up or down reaction.
No nose up or down reaction.

Questions.QuestionString: Compressible drag only occurs?
The vortex generator takes relatively high energy air from?
Answers: Inside the boundary layer and mixes it with low energy air in the boundary layer.
Outside the boundary layer and mixes it with high energy air in the boundary layer.
Outside the boundary layer and mixes it with high energy air in the boundary layer.

Questions.QuestionString: What is Thrust?
Answers: The force which moves the aircraft forward through the air.
The aerodynamic force which is parallel to the flight path.
The aerodynamic force which is parallel to the flight path.

Questions.QuestionString: What is Drag?
Answers: The aerodynamic force which is parallel to the flight path.
Provided by jet engines or by a propeller.
Provided by jet engines or by a propeller.

Questions.QuestionString: What is Lift?
Answers: The aerodynamic force which is ninety degrees to the flight path.
Provided by jet engines or by a propeller.
Provided by jet engines or by a propeller.

Questions.QuestionString: If an aircraft moves in yaw, what axis does it move about?
What does Lateral stability refer to?
Answers: The roll movement around the longitudinal axis.
The pitch movement around the lateral axis.
The pitch movement around the lateral axis.

Questions.QuestionString: What does Directional stability refer to?
Answers: The yaw movement around the vertical axis.
The roll movement around the longitudinal axis.
The roll movement around the longitudinal axis.

Questions.QuestionString: What does Longitudinal stability refer to?
Answers: The pitch movement around the lateral axis.
The yaw movement around the vertical axis.
The yaw movement around the vertical axis.

Questions.QuestionString: What is Weight?
How many degrees to the flight path of Lift force?
What can The center of gravity be thought of as?
What about the thrust and the drag?
Answers: The thrust line is below the drag line.
The thrust line and the drag line is the same.
The thrust line and the drag line is the same.

Questions.QuestionString: What is The moment arm?
Answers: The largest distance between the point of rotation and the line of action of the force.
The shortest distance between the point of rotation and the line of action of the force.
The shortest distance between the point of rotation and the line of action of the force.

Questions.QuestionString: When does an equilibrium exist?
Answers: The aircraft is in descent flight.
The aircraft is in steady, level flight.
The aircraft is in steady, level flight.

Questions.QuestionString: What does The lift on the wing has to carry?
Answers: The weight of the aircraft only
The weight of the aircraft and the downward acting stabilizer force.
The weight of the aircraft and the downward acting stabilizer force.

Questions.QuestionString: When Moments = Zero?
If the aircraft is to maintain altitude during a turn, the lift in the turn?
Answers: Must not be equal to the resultant of the centrifugal force and the weight.
Must be equal to the resultant of the centrifugal force or the weight.
Must be equal to the resultant of the centrifugal force or the weight.

Questions.QuestionString: The load factor ”n” is also called?
When an aircraft is in constant altitude, wings level flight, the lift is?
Answers: Equal to the weight of the aircraft.
Bigger to the weight of the aircraft.
Bigger to the weight of the aircraft.

Questions.QuestionString: The structural strength of the aircraft and consideration for passenger comfort limit?
Answers: The maximum angle of attack during a turn.
The maximum speed during a turn.
The maximum speed during a turn.

Questions.QuestionString: The load factor on military is much?
What happens when the aircraft is in cruise flight?
Answers: The coefficient of lift is much less than the maximum coefficient of lift.
The coefficient of lift is minimum.
The coefficient of lift is minimum.

Questions.QuestionString: When the aircraft is in low speed flight?
Answers: The coefficient of lift is at, or close to, the maximum.
The coefficient of lift is higher the maximum.
The coefficient of lift is higher the maximum.

Questions.QuestionString: What does pilot must do for the turn?
Answers: The pilot must decrease the speed.
The pilot must increase the speed to create the additional drag.
The pilot must increase the speed to create the additional drag.

Questions.QuestionString: The square root of the load factor is?
Answers: The stall speed during a turn divided by the stall speed during level flight.

Lateral stability is about?
The Aircraft Fin gives stability about which axis?
How many type of stability?

Answers: It returns to its original position of equilibrium.
It shows no tendency to roll back or away from its original position of equilibrium.
It shows no tendency to roll back or away from its original position of equilibrium.

Questions.QuestionString: What is Dutch roll?
What is the sideslip angle?
Answers: The angle between the aircraft centerline and the sideslip direction.
The angle between the aircraft centerline and the fuselage axis.

Questions.QuestionString: What is Longitudinal stability?
Answers: Longitudinal stability is the stability of the aircraft around the vertical axis.
Longitudinal stability is the stability of the aircraft around the longitudinal axis.
Longitudinal stability is the stability of the aircraft around the longitudinal axis.

Questions.QuestionString: What does The horizontal stabilizer produce?
Answers: A downward force during level flight.
An upward force during climb flight.
An upward force during climb flight.

Questions.QuestionString: What does The longitudinal stability depend on?

The angle of attack and the pitching moment effects of the vertical stabilizer and the wing.

Questions.QuestionString: When do dynamic stability apply?
Answers: Dynamic stability only applies if we have neutral static stability.
Dynamic stability only applies if we have negative static stability.
Dynamic stability only applies if we have negative static stability.
